hints.label: def-swarm-state-space-closure
hints.title: Swarm State Space
hints.content:
249: :label: def-swarm-state-space-closure
250: 
251: The **swarm configuration** at discrete time $k$ is:
252: 
253: $$
254: Z_k := (X_k, V_k, \mathcal{I}_k) \in \Omega
255: 
256: $$
257: 
258: where:
259: - $X_k = (x_{1,k}, \ldots, x_{N,k}) \in \mathcal{X}^N$: Positions of all walkers
260: - $V_k = (v_{1,k}, \ldots, v_{N,k}) \in \mathbb{R}^{Nd}$: Velocities of all walkers
261: - $\mathcal{I}_k$: Information Graph adjacency structure (which walkers are IG-connected)
262: 
263: **State space:**
264: 
265: $$
266: \Omega := \mathcal{X}^N \times \mathbb{R}^{Nd} \times \mathcal{G}_N
267: 
268: $$
269: 
270: where $\mathcal{G}_N$ is the space of weighted undirected graphs on $N$ vertices.

hints.label: prop-baoab-markov
hints.title: BAOAB Chain is a Markov Process
hints.content:
276: :label: prop-baoab-markov
277: 
278: The sequence $\{Z_k\}_{k \geq 0}$ is a **time-homogeneous Markov chain** on $\Omega$ with transition kernel:
279: 
280: $$
281: P(Z_{k+1} \in A \mid Z_0, \ldots, Z_k) = P(Z_{k+1} \in A \mid Z_k) =: \mathbb{P}(Z_k, A)
282: 
283: $$
284: 
285: where $\mathbb{P}(z, \cdot)$ is the BAOAB transition kernel (Definition 1.2 in [02_computational_equivalence.md](02_computational_equivalence.md)).

hints.label: def-past-future-cst
hints.title: Past and Future on CST
hints.content:
297: :label: def-past-future-cst
298: 
299: For an episode $e \in \mathcal{E}$ born at time $t^{\rm b}_e$ and dying at time $t^{\rm d}_e$:
300: 
301: **CST Past:** The **genealogical history** is the rooted path in the CST from the root episode to $e$:
302: 
303: $$
304: H_{\text{CST}}(e) := \{e_0 \to e_1 \to \cdots \to e_n = e\}
305: 
306: $$
307: 
308: where $e_{i} \prec e_{i+1}$ are parent-child relations (Definition 1.1 in [01_fractal_set.md](01_fractal_set.md)).
309: 
310: **CST Future:** The set of all possible descendant paths from $e$:
311: 
312: $$
313: F_{\text{CST}}(e) := \{\text{paths } e = e_0 \to e_1 \to e_2 \to \cdots\}
314: 
315: $$
316: 
317: **Embedded state:** At each time $k$ along the history, store the walker state:
318: 
319: $$
320: H(e, k) := (x_k, v_k) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d

hints.label: def-ig-augmented-past
hints.title: IG-Augmented Past
hints.content:
326: :label: def-ig-augmented-past
327: 
328: The **full past** includes IG correlations. At each time $k$ in the history, record:
329: 
330: $$
331: H_{\text{full}}(e, k) := (x_k, v_k, \mathcal{N}_{\text{IG}}(k))
332: 
333: $$
334: 
335: where $\mathcal{N}_{\text{IG}}(k) \subseteq \mathcal{A}_k$ is the set of IG neighbors of walker $i$ at time $k$ (all walkers $j$ such that $w_{ij}(k) > 0$).
336: 
337: **Rationale:** The IG encodes quantum correlations that influence future evolution via:
338: 1. Companion selection probability in cloning (Definition 5.7.1 in [01_fragile_gas_framework.md](../01_fragile_gas_framework.md))
339: 2. Viscous coupling forces in Adaptive Gas (Chapter 7)

hints.label: thm-causal-state-markov-reduction
hints.title: Causal States on Fractal Set
hints.content:
345: :label: def-causal-states-fractal-set
346: 
347: Two episodes $e, e'$ are in the same **causal state** $\sigma \in \Sigma_\varepsilon^{\text{Fractal}}$ if their augmented pasts lead to identical conditional distributions over futures:
348: 
349: $$
350: P(F_{\text{CST}}(e), F_{\text{IG}}(e) \mid H_{\text{full}}(e)) = P(F_{\text{CST}}(e'), F_{\text{IG}}(e') \mid H_{\text{full}}(e'))
351: 
352: $$
353: 
354: where:
355: - $F_{\text{CST}}(e)$ is the CST descendant structure
356: - $F_{\text{IG}}(e)$ is the future IG connectivity evolution
357: 
358: **Simplified Markovian form:** Since the BAOAB chain is Markovian (Proposition {prf:ref}`prop-baoab-markov`), the entire history of pasts reduces to the **current swarm configuration**. We have the following rigorous theorem:
359: 
360: :::{prf:theorem} Causal State Reduction for Markov Processes
361: :label: thm-causal-state-markov-reduction
362: 
363: For a time-homogeneous Markov process $\{Z_k\}_{k \geq 0}$ with transition kernel $\mathbb{P}(z, dz')$, two pasts $\overleftarrow{z}_t$ and $\overleftarrow{z}'_t$ are causally equivalent if and only if their terminal states are equivalent:
364: 
365: $$
366: P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid \overleftarrow{Z}_t = \overleftarrow{z}_t) = P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid \overleftarrow{Z}_t = \overleftarrow{z}'_t) \iff P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid Z_t = z_t) = P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid Z_t = z'_t)
367: 
368: $$
369: 
370: where $z_t, z'_t$ are the terminal states of the pasts.
371: 
372: **Proof:** By the Markov property:
373: 
374: $$
375: P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid \overleftarrow{Z}_t) = P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid Z_t)
376: 
377: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-156
hints.title: State Discretization
hints.content:
400: :class: note
401: 
402: Since $\mathcal{X}$ and $\mathbb{R}^d$ are continuous, we must discretize to obtain a finite ε-machine.
403: 
404: **Spatial discretization:** Partition $\mathcal{X}$ into cells of size $\delta_x$ (e.g., lattice spacing $a$).
405: 
406: **Velocity discretization:** Partition $\mathbb{R}^d$ into bins of size $\delta_v$.
407: 
408: **IG discretization:** Two IG structures are equivalent if they have the same adjacency pattern (ignoring small edge weight differences below threshold $\varepsilon_{\text{IG}}$).

hints.label: thm-epsilon-machine-baoab
hints.title: ε-Machine Transition Kernel from BAOAB
hints.content:
416: :label: thm-epsilon-machine-baoab
417: 
418: The ε-machine transition probabilities are determined by the BAOAB kernel $\mathbb{P}(z, dz')$ and the cloning/IG update rules.
419: 
420: For causal states $\sigma, \sigma' \in \Sigma_\varepsilon^{\text{Fractal}}$ and observable symbol $a \in \mathcal{A}$ (e.g., a discretized observable like "alive" or "cloned"):
421: 
422: $$
423: T_\varepsilon(\sigma' \mid \sigma, a) = \int_{z \in \sigma} \int_{z' \in \sigma'} \mathbb{P}(z, dz') \cdot \mathbb{1}_{[o(z') = a]} \cdot \frac{d\mu_{\text{QSD}}(z)}{\mu_{\text{QSD}}(\sigma)}
424: 
425: $$
426: 
427: where:
428: - $\mu_{\text{QSD}}$ is the quasi-stationary distribution (Definition 2.1 in [04_convergence.md](../04_convergence.md))
429: - $o(z)$ is the observable function (e.g., whether the walker cloned)
430: - The integral weights by the equilibrium probability within each causal state
hints.raw_directive:
413: ### 3.3. Transition Dynamics of the Fractal Set ε-Machine
414: 
415: :::{prf:theorem} ε-Machine Transition Kernel from BAOAB
416: :label: thm-epsilon-machine-baoab
417: 
418: The ε-machine transition probabilities are determined by the BAOAB kernel $\mathbb{P}(z, dz')$ and the cloning/IG update rules.
419: 
420: For causal states $\sigma, \sigma' \in \Sigma_\varepsilon^{\text{Fractal}}$ and observable symbol $a \in \mathcal{A}$ (e.g., a discretized observable like "alive" or "cloned"):
421: 
422: $$
423: T_\varepsilon(\sigma' \mid \sigma, a) = \int_{z \in \sigma} \int_{z' \in \sigma'} \mathbb{P}(z, dz') \cdot \mathbb{1}_{[o(z') = a]} \cdot \frac{d\mu_{\text{QSD}}(z)}{\mu_{\text{QSD}}(\sigma)}
424: 
425: $$
426: 
427: where:
428: - $\mu_{\text{QSD}}$ is the quasi-stationary distribution (Definition 2.1 in [04_convergence.md](../04_convergence.md))
429: - $o(z)$ is the observable function (e.g., whether the walker cloned)
430: - The integral weights by the equilibrium probability within each causal state

hints.title: Stationary ε-Machine
hints.content:
436: :label: cor-stationary-epsilon-machine
437: 
438: Under the QSD, the Fractal Set ε-machine reaches a **stationary distribution** over causal states:
439: 
440: $$
441: \pi_\varepsilon(\sigma) = \mu_{\text{QSD}}(\sigma) = \int_{z \in \sigma} d\mu_{\text{QSD}}(z)
442: 
443: $$

hints.label: def-statistical-complexity
hints.title: Statistical Complexity
hints.content:
453: :label: def-statistical-complexity
454: 
455: The **statistical complexity** of the Fractal Set is the entropy of the causal state distribution:
456: 
457: $$
458: C_\mu := H(\Sigma_\varepsilon) = -\sum_{\sigma \in \Sigma_\varepsilon} \pi_\varepsilon(\sigma) \log \pi_\varepsilon(\sigma)
459: 
460: $$
461: 
462: **Interpretation:** $C_\mu$ measures the memory required to achieve optimal prediction. It quantifies the "complexity" of the predictive model.
hints.raw_directive:

hints.label: def-entropy-rate
hints.title: Entropy Rate
hints.content:
468: :label: def-entropy-rate
469: 
470: The **entropy rate** is the conditional entropy of the next symbol given the causal state:
471: 
472: $$
473: h_\mu := H(X_t \mid \Sigma_t) = -\sum_{\sigma, a} \pi_\varepsilon(\sigma) T_\varepsilon(a \mid \sigma) \log T_\varepsilon(a \mid \sigma)
474: 
475: $$

hints.label: prop-bound-excess-entropy
hints.title: Bound Excess Entropy
hints.content:
481: :label: prop-bound-excess-entropy
482: 
483: The **excess entropy** $E$ (mutual information between past and future) satisfies:
484: 
485: $$
486: E = I(\overleftarrow{X}; \overrightarrow{X}) \leq C_\mu
487: 
488: $$
489: 
490: with equality if and only if the process is **cryptic** (some causal states are not distinguishable from finite pasts).
